  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
The scourge of terrorism got worse last year. A
  new report says attacks worldwide jumped 25 percent — and that's not
  all. David Martin at the Pentagon will have the latest on what the report
  means for the war on terror.
 
A victory in that war was won in Britain today. Five defendants
  were found guilty of plotting a massive terrorist attack. They were
  discovered during one of the country’s most intensive surveillance
  operations ever. Sheila MacVicar will have the latest.
 
A woman known as the D.C. Madam has everyone talking
  inside the Beltway and beyond. She says she's not naming names —
  exactly. Instead, she has handed over her phone records, which reportedly
  list prominent individuals — among them executives, the head of a conservative
  think-tank and an administration economist — as clients. Bob Orr will
  have the story.
 
Venezuelan president Hugo Chavez claimed today that
  Cuban president Fidel Castro is back "in charge"  after being
  out of the public eye for more than nine months while recovering from
  intestinal surgery. But is the 80-year-old Castro well enough to lead? Lara
  Logan, our chief foreign correspondent, will report from Cuba.
 
We will also take you to Shandong Province, China,
  known as the world’s salad bowl — it exports more produce than
  anywhere else on the planet. It's an open secret that manufacturers there add
  melamine to pet food to boost apparent protein content — a fact that
  has brought the entire region under intense international scrutiny. Can Shandong convince the
  world its products are safe to eat? Barry Petersen will report.
 
Had you heard of melamine before it tainted pet
  food? The chemical can to be used to coat tabletops, fertilize crops and even
  masquerades as a protein. Nancy Cordes will have more.
 
Cigarettes and drugs can be addictive, but what
  about your PC? Daniel Sieberg will begin our series "Caught in the
  Web" with the story of a family torn apart by computer-game addiction. 
 
Finally, our chief White House correspondent Jim
  Axelrod will report on White House press secretary Tony Snow’s return
  to work five weeks after doctors discovered a recurrence of his cancer. Snow
  said he feels "unbelievably lucky and unbelievably blessed."
 
I hope you’ll join us.
 




Katie Couric
